thread.title: Hardware shops given two months to tag animal-derived products
thread.title_full: Hardware shops given two months to tag animal-derived products

author: MARTIN CARVALHO
title: Hardware shops given two months to tag animal-derived products
text:
by martin carvalho Clarifying the issue: (From left) Kang, Hamzah, Low and Hong speaking during the press conference. 
KUALA LUMPUR: Traders selling paint brushes are given up to two months to put labels on the brushes to differentiate products that can be sold to Muslims and non-Muslims, says Domestic Trade, Cooperatives and Consumerism Minister Datuk Seri Hamzah Zainuddin. 
He also ordered a stop to all operations to search and seize paint brushes made of pig bristles or dog hair following a Cabinet meeting on the matter. 
The minister, however, rejected calls for a pig logo on the paint brushes. 
“It is not necessary to include such a logo as there are already laws to govern the labelling of animal-derived products,” he said. 
He advised traders to separate animal derived products and label them accordingly. 
“If they are derived from animals, say so. If they are unsure, they will also have to state it,” he told a press conference, held to clarify the issue here yesterday. 
The Muslim Consumers Association of Malaysia’s chief activist Datuk Nadzim Johan had suggested the logo. 
“Why make it difficult? It’s simple, just place a label to say that the products are animal derived,” Hamzah said. 
Over 2,000 paint brushes that were suspected to be made from pig bristles were seized recently in a nationwide crackdown. 
Hamzah said enforcement officers were told to educate the traders instead of penalising them as the problem was due to manufacturers who did not provide the proper labelling before distributing the paint brushes to the traders. 
It would be sufficient for traders to label the brushes with words “products made of animal bristles”, he added. 
“We don’t want enforcement officers to go to the extreme and make it look as though it is a big problem in the country.” 
He expressed disappointment that the paint brush issue had been turned into a racial and religious controversy. 
“I am aware that there are groups or NGOs who will use this to split the people and blame the Government,” he added. 
He also said it was not necessary to have a separate halal label for non-food products, as suggested by Nadzim. 
While acknowledging that the halal logo was a must for food products, Hamzah said it was not a requirement for non-food products. 
Malaysia Metal Wholesalers Association chairman Low Cheng Ho, who was present at the press conference, said traders would be informed to label their products accordingly. 
“If they don’t do it, then action should be taken against them,” he said. 
The others who were at the conference were Federation of Malaysia Hardware, Machinery and Building Materials Associations president Loh Foo, SME Association of Malaysia president Datuk Michael Kang Hua Keong, Malaysian Gifts and Premium Association president Alan Ong Yeow Fooi and Federation of Sundry Goods and Merchants Associations president Hong Chee Meng.
